[[Image:SHARP logo.jpg|thumb|right|SHARP logo]] '''Skinheads Against Racial Prejudice''' ('''SHARP''') are [[Anti-racism|anti-racist]] [[skinhead]]s who oppose [[neo-Nazis]] and other political racists, particularly if those racists identify themselves as skinheads.
SHARPs recognise the [[Multiracial|biracial]] origins of the skinhead [[subculture]], and resent what they see as the hijacking of the skinhead name by [[white power skinhead]]s - who are consequently designated as "boneheads" by some SHARPs. The SHARP logo is based on the logo of [[Trojan Records]], which originally mainly released black [[Jamaica]]n [[ska]], [[rocksteady]] and [[reggae]] artists. Beyond the issue of anti-racism, there is no official political ideology of SHARP.
==History==
The original [[skinhead]] subculture started in the [[United Kingdom]] in late 1960s, and had heavy British [[Mod (subculture)|mod]] and [[Jamaica]]n [[rude boy]] influences, including a love for [[ska]] and [[soul music]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2005/is_1_38/ai_n6234788/pg_1 | work=Journal of Social History | title=Subcultures, pop music and politics: skinheads and "Nazi rock" in England and Germany | first=Timothy S. | last=Brown | year=2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Old Skool Jim |first= |title=Trojan Skinhead Reggae Box Set liner notes |publisher=Trojan Records |date= |location=London |id=TJETD169}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Marshall |first=George |title=Spirit of '69 - A Skinhead Bible |publisher=S.T. Publishing |date=1991 |location=Dunoon, Scotland |isbn=1-898927-10-3)}}</ref><ref>[http://www.reggaereggaereggae.com/Special%20Articles.htm Special Articles<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Although some skinheads (including [[Black people|black]] skinheads) had engaged in ''[[Paki bashing]]'' (random violence against [[British Pakistani|Pakistanis]] and other [[British Asian|South Asian immigrants]]), skinheads were not associated with an organized racist political movement in the 1960s.<ref> Marshall, George. Skinhead Nation. ST Publishing, 1996. ISBN 1-898927-45-6, ISBN 978-1-898927-45-7.</ref><ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20050929223759/http://www.trojanrecords.net/articles/monty2.htm Monty Montgomery of the Pyramids/Symarip interview]</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,909318,00.html?promoid=googlep | work=Time | title=Britain: The Skinheads | date=1970-06-08 | accessdate=2010-05-23}}</ref> However, in the late 1970s, a skinhead revival in the UK included a sizable [[White nationalism|white nationalist]] faction, involving organizations such as the [[British National Front|National Front]], [[British Movement]], [[Rock Against Communism]] and in the late eighties [[Blood and Honor]]. Because of this, the mainstream media began to label the whole skinhead identity as [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]]. This new [[white power skinhead]] movement then spread to other countries, including the [[United States]].
Skinheads Against Racial Prejudice was started in [[New York City]] in 1987 by Marcus Pacheco & Stevan M as a way to show that the skinhead subculture is not based on racism and political extremism.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20070927212546/http://www.skinheadnation.co.uk/newyorkskinheads.htm Skinhead Nation, chapter: The Big Apple Bites Back] (archived)</ref> André Schlesinger (and his [[Oi!]] band [[The Press (band)|The Press]]) and Jason O'Toole (vocalist of the [[hardcore punk]] group [[Life's Blood]]) were among SHARP's early supporters. In 1989, Roddy Moreno of the Welsh Oi! band [[The Oppressed]] visited New York City and met a few SHARP members. On his return to the [[United Kingdom]], he designed a new SHARP logo based on the Trojan Reggae labels design and started promoting SHARP ideals to British skinheads.<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/#!/pages/The-Oppressed-sharp-attitude/108930239188615 The Oppressed; Official Website<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/music/sites/oppressed/ BBC - Wales - The Oppressed<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> SHARP then spread throughout Europe and in other continents.<ref>[http://www.skinheadnation.co.uk/sharpskinheads.htm SHARP skinheads<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In the UK and other European countries, the SHARP attitude was more based on the individual than on organized groups. In the 2000s, SHARP is thought to have become more of an individual designation than an official organization.
